elpacho1313 wrote:
>> However, from your frontier report, it looks like most queues have 
>> finished, which implies some sort of limit has been successfully 
>> applied. Do you see URLs in the crawl.log with 'hops-path' strings (the 
>> collection of uppercase letters like 'LL' or 'LE') longer than two 
>> characters?

> No, all are two chars long, does that mean that no one of my crawls is
> going deeper than 2 links???

Yes, nothing is deeper than 2 hops, so your rule is working. (Though, as 
your other message mentioned that a MatchesRegExpDecideRule appears 
after it, it's possible that if that later rule is configured to ACCEPT 
some matching URIs, it could ACCEPT things the TooManyHops rule REJECTed.)

> If that is the case what is the meaning of this:
> 
> 425 average depth
> 
> that apears on the console when the job is running.

That appears directly under a line like "1199 deepest queue".

These actually refer to the length of individual queues, and should 
probably read 'longest queue' or 'average length' to avoid the risk of 
confusion with tree/graph depth.

> I also would like to know your opinion about something: I've been
> working on these for three days and still didn't obtain good results
> and I'm afraid that my boss (this is my first assignment) would think
> that I'm not good at the job. So my question is: how much do you think
> or know that people take to learn to use Heritrix properly?
> I'm I going a bit too slow.

There's really no way to say. Everyone is different in their background 
and goals. Also, Heritrix is not packaged commercial software; it takes 
some work, especially if you want to do anything custom.

- Gordon @ IA
